text: {"grade": 1, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to state that a lender's failure to make reasonable inquiries about occupiers can cause an overriding interest to bind them, even if it was not discovered. The candidate answer addresses this under section 2A, stating: 'If you were living in the property at the time of the remortgage, or if there was any evidence (e.g., emails, texts, utility bills in your name) that the bank *should* have known about your interest, a court *might* rule that the bank had **constructive notice** of your beneficial interest.' This directly covers the concept that the bank's failure to inquire (leading to constructive notice) can bind them to an unregistered interest (the overriding interest).", "criterion_id": "94c14c26-3d41-4b09-abe3-a18f253ce007"}
